data.question: What is the chemical formula for tris-sarcosine calcium chloride?
At what temperature does tris-sarcosine calcium chloride exhibit a second-order displacive phase transition?
Is ferrielectricity more common in liquid crystals or crystalline solids?
Can the phase transition temperature of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride be lowered to 0 K?
data.answer: Yes, via Br or I substitution

data.question: What is the significance of the size of the primitive unit cell not increasing in the AFE phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride?
data.answer: It is unusual and suggests ferrielectricity without change in primitive cell size

data.question: Is the low-temperature phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride polar or nonpolar?
Does tris-sarcosine calcium chloride exhibit a ferroelectric to antiferroelectric phase transition?
data.answer: No, it exhibits a paraelectric to ferrielectric transition

data.question: Is the ferrielectric phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride considered a textbook paradigm of ferrielectricity?
True or False: The ferrielectric phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride is achieved only at high fields.
True or False: The primitive unit cell size increases in the AFE phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride.
True or False: Ferrielectricity in tris-sarcosine calcium chloride is due to hydrogen bonding.
True or False: The ferrielectric phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride can be switched electrically.
True or False: The high-pressure ambient temperature phase of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride is polar.
True or False: The structural phase transition at 64 K in tris-sarcosine calcium chloride involves a doubling of the unit cell.

What is the role of Br or I substitution in the phase transition of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride?
data.answer: It can lower the phase transition temperature to 0 K

data.question: What evidence supports the paraelectric to ferrielectric transition in tris-sarcosine calcium chloride?
data.answer: Measurement of hysteresis loops and polarization below T = 64 K

data.question: What does the presence of a large bias field in the polarization hysteresis loops of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride indicate?
data.answer: It suggests a ferrielectric phase with two polarization components, one switchable and one not

data.question: What is the measured spontaneous polarization of tris-sarcosine calcium chloride at 77 K?
What structural feature allows tris-sarcosine calcium chloride to exhibit ferrielectricity?
data.answer: Four polarizations per unit cell in both its PE and FE phase
